awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Entanglement, Pairing and Superfluidity at the Interface between Atomic and Nuclear Physics.
awd_abstract_narration:
Many areas in physics are entering an information age, with computation at the forefront of research. One of the key notions in this new era is the quantum-mechanical property of entanglement, which characterizes how quantum particles are correlated with each other purely as a result of their quantum-mechanical nature. The influence of inter-particle interactions on entanglement is a challenging question, as interactions (in particular strong ones) drive phase transitions and are responsible for intriguing properties of matter. Information-related quantities, such as the entanglement entropy, play an essential role in quantum phase transitions and are central to seemingly disparate areas, such as quantum computation and black holes. The PI will leverage computational progress in atomic, nuclear and condensed matter physics to pursue a deeper understanding of strongly interacting superfluid systems at the interface between those areas, where entanglement properties remain largely unexplored. This project will provide precise predictions of entanglement and its correlation with thermodynamic observables across a wide variety of systems. Graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged at multiple levels, with emphasis on an ongoing curriculum and track-developing collaboration with the University of North Carolina at Pembroke.

This project aims for a precise characterization of a wide range of strongly coupled, non-relativistic, few- and many-fermion systems of relevance to atomic, molecular, and nuclear physics. The systems considered here will include multiple spatial dimensions, free space, harmonic traps, and weakly to strongly interacting regimes. Thermodynamic properties (static, dynamic, structural, and pairing correlations) and their connection to entanglement (entanglement entropies, mutual information) will be determined using non-perturbative approaches, including numerical lattice field theory methods as well as semi-analytic expansions (e.g. the virial and operator-product expansions). To this end, advanced computational methods and algorithms will be implemented and new approaches will be explored to calculate entanglement entropies. The methods (codes, scripts, technical notes) and the data (from auxiliary field configurations to the physical results) will be made available online.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed a variety of problems at the interface between atomic and nuclear physics, centered around the characterization of the thermodynamic and entanglement behavior of a wide range of systems. Understanding such behavior is essential for understanding the nature of quantum many-body physics (which governs systems made out of many quantum particles, such as atoms, electrons, neutrons).

One of the main challenges in this field is computational in nature: quantum mechanics, when many particles are present, is notoriously difficult to calculate. To that end, computers are used, but even then the available algorithms are few and far between (in spite of substantial progress). This project advanced that frontier by devising new algorithms and applying them to essential problems of interest to atomic, condensed matter, and nuclear physics.

In particular, two new algorithms were designed to calculate the so-called Renyi entanglement entropy, which provides one way to understand matter at low temperatures (quantum phase transitions). Entanglement is one of the key properties of quantum mechanics that enable quantum computing, but has proven very difficult to calculate. The algorithm proposed is straightforward to implement in any field-integral representation of a quantum theory, such as those used in quantum chromodynamics (QCD). The results were tested in strongly coupled ultracold atoms theories.

Among the main computational difficulties of quantum many-body physics is the so-called sign problem. This problem appears, unfortunately, for most applications of interest. When setting up a Monte Carlo calculation for such applications, a probability is required, but the natural candidate for such a probability turns out to be a complex number (or a sign-changing real number), which spoils the algorithms as probabilities must be non-negative real numbers. To address this problem, and so enlarge the set of possible results one could reach, this project investigated the so-called complex Langevin method, applying it to multiple non-relativistic theories (such as those that describe cold atoms and dilute neutron matter in neutron stars). The method relies in an interpretation of complex probabilities as a way to redefine the underlying theory and has proven sucessful even when the interactions are strong. An extensive review article covering many approaches to the sign problem was published in Physics Reports.

Another highlight of this project is the realization that, even with certain advances in addressing the sign problem, there are applications that suffer from very similar statistical ailments but which require different, non-stochastic approaches. One such case is the calculation of virial coefficients. These are important because they capture, in a completely non-perturbative way, the behavior of matter at high temperature and low density, by breaking up the quantum many-body problem into few bodies, adding one body at a time. The proposed method is to set up and entirely analytic process where the required coefficients are calculated using automated algebra. The resulting approach was able to calculate reliably for the first time up to the fifth order in the virial expansion, resolving a previous tension between theory and experiment already present at fourth order. This technique is now being extended to new systems and quantities as part of a new project.

This project supported, at least in part, the PhD studies of 6 students, who successfully defended their theses between 2015 and 2020. In addition, the project supported interactions with faculty and students at UNC Pembroke.
Throughout the lifetime of the award, and as a result of the work of the above students and other collaborations, about 30 peer-reviewed publications were produced, whose results were presented at several conferences, seminars, and colloquia in the US and abroad.
